text:
Hi guys, I have a Betfair account that's been set up by a client who is based in Asia. I have been told that all betfair code needs to be ran from a Hong Kong server. I am running into connection problems when I run some flumine based price scraping code from an AWS server in HK. I see a huge ramp up in the latency and then a fairly nasty connection error message:

text: So the connection error is on the account details endpoint, whats the setup here in terms of number of markets?

elements.text: So the connection error is on the account details endpoint, whats the setup here in terms of number of markets?

text: I imagine any connection from HK is gonna be slow as

elements.text: I imagine any connection from HK is gonna be slow as

text: I have two strategies that both pull all win market prices from AUS

elements.text: I have two strategies that both pull all win market prices from AUS

text: typically the latency from HK seems to be stable at around 0.5s

elements.text: typically the latency from HK seems to be stable at around 0.5s

text: what killed it? CPU ok?

elements.text: what killed it? CPU ok?

text: I was going to ask about that as well. I have noticed that when I run my flumine code, or a previous betfairlightweight price scraper I have on the HK box I see the RAM usage slowly creep up until the process is killed. I had previously tried to flush the queue every 10 seconds (presuming it was the queue gathering data) and I still saw the RAM usage increase. The same code ran on a UK based AWS instance for my own use didnt have the memory problems.

elements.text: I was going to ask about that as well. I have noticed that when I run my flumine code, or a previous betfairlightweight price scraper I have on the HK box I see the RAM usage slowly creep up until the process is killed. I had previously tried to flush the queue every 10 seconds (presuming it was the queue gathering data) and I still saw the RAM usage increase. The same code ran on a UK based AWS instance for my own use didnt have the memory problems.

text: there are no known memory leaks in bflw or flumine

elements.text: there are no known memory leaks in bflw or flumine

text: yeah must be something to do with running the code on the HK server?

elements.text: yeah must be something to do with running the code on the HK server?

text: looks like it, the way the latency increases like that isn't good, why HK?

elements.text: looks like it, the way the latency increases like that isn't good, why HK?

elements.text: thats one strat and the other is a class that pushes to redis

text: are you confident that isn't blocking? / slow?

elements.text: are you confident that isn't blocking? / slow?

text: not confident at all no haha

elements.text: not confident at all no haha

text: remove it and try again

elements.text: remove it and try again

elements.text: ok will do. cheers Liam

text: Use another account to do the scraping in a sensible location?

text: I can't replicate this, tried doing a few things and the middleware (EC) or process.py (E) picks all orders up

elements.text: I can't replicate this, tried doing a few things and the middleware (EC) or process.py (E) picks all orders up

text: I can get the middleware to pick it up (if I pick up ALL rather than EXECUTION_COMPLETE), but not process, must be a weird edge case!

elements.text: I can get the middleware to pick it up (if I pick up ALL rather than EXECUTION_COMPLETE), but not process, must be a weird edge case!

text: Managed to re-create finally, it is when an order is partially matched, then replaced. When you re-start it doesn't seem to get picked up (however I'm dubious it always happens, so am wondering if there's some other condition too)

elements.text: Managed to re-create finally, it is when an order is partially matched, then replaced. When you re-start it doesn't seem to get picked up (however I'm dubious it always happens, so am wondering if there's some other condition too)

text:
Being across 2 sessions (i.e. after a shutdown), this is a very tricky one to debug!

Will try to do a forced update of Flumine, although pretty sure I'm using the latest version.

Will work on trying to pinpoint the issue.

elements.text:
Being across 2 sessions (i.e. after a shutdown), this is a very tricky one to debug!

Will try to do a forced update of Flumine, although pretty sure I'm using the latest version.

text: The only other condition that is consistent, is that the placed date of the original order, is never today.

text: Is it mandatory that your server is located in the same country as your Betfair account? I assumed yes but it would be much better to have the server in London/Dublin instead. Anyone with experience on this?

elements.text: Is it mandatory that your server is located in the same country as your Betfair account? I assumed yes but it would be much better to have the server in London/Dublin instead. Anyone with experience on this?

text:
```if (
    order.bet_id and order.bet_id != current_order.bet_id
):  # replaceOrder handling (hacky)

    if str(current_order.bet_id) == '235032486097':
        print(current_order.bet_id, current_order.market_id, order.bet_id, order)

    order = markets.get_order_from_bet_id(
        market_id=current_order.market_id,
        bet_id=current_order.bet_id,
    )

    if order is None:
        print(current_order.bet_id, order)
        continue```
So looking at process, this is the point where it goes wrong, when it tries to get the order from the blotter it can't, the output returned is as follows:

```235032486097 1.176694234 234874322650 Order 234874322650: Execution complete
235032486097 None```

elements.text: So looking at process, this is the point where it goes wrong, when it tries to get the order from the blotter it can't, the output returned is as follows:
